channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Russian forces pushed away from Kharkiv; international effort to evacuate Mariupol resumes
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to tell Ukraine’s legislature Tuesday that this is the country's “finest hour.”

item.title: U.S. warns Russia may annex more Ukrainian territory
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.description: U.S. diplomats will resume limited activities in Lviv. Nancy Pelosi meets the Polish president. Jill Biden to travel to Romania and Slovakia.

item.title: Culture, interrupted: Artists and artistic freedom in Russia face dark times
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: These are dark times in a country with one of the world’s richest cultural legacies. As Russia wages its war on Ukraine, the Kremlin is cracking down to quell dissent within its own borders.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Russian forces pushed away from Kharkiv; international effort to evacuate Mariupol resumes
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to tell Ukraine’s legislature Tuesday that this is the country's “finest hour.”

item.title: U.S. warns Russia may annex more Ukrainian territory
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.description: U.S. diplomats will resume limited activities in Lviv. Nancy Pelosi meets the Polish president. Jill Biden to travel to Romania and Slovakia.

item.title: Culture, interrupted: Artists and artistic freedom in Russia face dark times
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: These are dark times in a country with one of the world’s richest cultural legacies. As Russia wages its war on Ukraine, the Kremlin is cracking down to quell dissent within its own borders.

item.title: The war in Ukraine boosts Belarusian opposition
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The Belarusian opposition wants to see tougher sanctions placed on Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko, including asset freezes on cronyism allies and state firms along the lines of what the West has deployed against Russia.

item.title: Russia planning to annex new areas of Ukraine, U.S. intelligence finds
item.dc:creator: Missy Ryan
item.description: Claiming Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson would be an attempt by Russia to control of much of Ukraine’s east despite ongoing struggles on the battlefield.

item.title: Régine, who built a discotheque empire, dies at 92
item.dc:creator: Harrison Smith
item.description: The “Queen of the Night” ran nearly two-dozen exclusive clubs, including in Paris and New York.

item.title: Jill Biden to meet with displaced Ukrainians on Mother’s Day in Slovakia
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: On a tour to Romania and Slovakia, first lady Jill Biden will meet with displaced Ukrainian families, U.S. service members and embassy staffers.

item.title: Dominican Republic presses Haiti to probe disappearance of diplomat
item.dc:creator: Amanda Coletta
item.description: Dominican officials believe Carlos Guillén Tatis was abducted while traveling through a neighborhood notorious for kidnappings.

item.title: Some Eid celebrations marred by war, others return to pre-covid scale
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall
item.description: In Ukraine, some members of a small and diverse Muslim community gathered amid the devastation of the war for morning prayers at the Kyiv Islamic Cultural Center.

item.title: Sinn Fein could see landmark win in Northern Ireland elections Thursday
item.dc:creator: Amanda Ferguson
item.description: If Sinn Fein wins, it will be the first time a party devoted to Irish unification has held the most seats in the regional assembly.

item.title: Ricardo Alarcón, powerful Cuban foreign minister, dies at 84
item.dc:creator: Phil Davison
item.description: He was seen as a potential successor to Fidel Castro and played a central role in the Elián González custody saga.

item.title: E.U. close to deal on Russian oil phaseout; Hungary, Slovakia object
item.dc:creator: Emily Rauhala
item.description: Talks gained momentum last week after a major holdout, Germany, softened its opposition.

item.title: Maps of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Washington Post Staff
item.description: Russia has launched an extensive assault on Ukraine. We're mapping how Russian troops are advancing.

item.title: Israel wants apology after Russia’s Lavrov compares Zelensky to Hitler
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix
item.description: Israel demanded an apology from the Russian government for employing a discredited antisemitic trope.

item.title: Pandemic, war, politics hamper global push for climate action
item.dc:creator: Brady Dennis

item.title: The drug trade now flourishing in Afghanistan: Meth
item.dc:creator: Susannah George
item.description: Long a hub for opium production, the country is fueling a new global drug crisis.

item.title: The agonizing second burial of Andriy Voznenko
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton
item.description: After two months of war, Ukrainian villages mark their days with funerals as bodies are found and identified.

item.title: Soviet flags keep rising over Russian-occupied Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin cloaks himself as the bearer of all sorts of mythic, historical legacies that stretch back beyond the Soviet era.

item.title: The ‘Ghost of Kyiv’ was never alive, Ukrainian air force says
item.dc:creator: Lateshia Beachum
item.description: The Ghost of Kyiv is one of the most successful pieces of propaganda promoting the prowess of the nation’s fighting forces and lifting morale.

item.title: Mariupol evacuation push resumes; Pelosi met Zelensky in Kyiv
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor
item.description: Russian-occupied Kherson faces new restrictions, and fighting continues in Kharkiv.

item.title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
item.dc:creator: Rod McGuirk | AP
item.description: An Australian man was sentenced to 12 years and seven months in prison for the 1988 murder of an American who fell off a Sydney cliff that was known as a gay meeting place

item.title: Ukrainian refugees at camp in Mexico City await US action
item.dc:creator: Christopher Sherman | AP
item.description: On a dusty field on the east side of Mexico’s sprawling capital, some 500 Ukrainian refugees are waiting in large tents under a searing sun for the United States government to tell them they can come

item.title: Muslims mark Eid al-Fitr holiday with joy, worry
item.dc:creator: Mariam Fam, Niniek Karmini and Kathy Gannon | AP
item.description: Muslims are observing the Islamic holiday of Eid al-Fitr, typically marked with communal prayers, celebratory gatherings around festive meals and new clothes

item.title: Argentine nuns accuse archbishop, others of gender violence
item.dc:creator: Almudena Calatrava | AP
item.description: Several feminist groups are calling for protests in support of a community of cloistered nuns who have caused shockwaves by accusing the archbishop of a northern Argentine province and other church officials of gender-based psychological and physical violence

item.title: Amazon tribes turn the tables on intruders with social media
item.dc:creator: Fabiano Maisonnave | AP
item.description: Indigenous Brazilians in the Amazon rainforest have endured years of scant recourse when prospectors and landgrabbers do violence in their territories

item.title: Rights groups criticize El Salvador's mass gang roundups
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Human rights groups are criticizing El Salvador’s massive arrests of suspected gang members

item.title: Death in Ukraine's Kharkiv is everywhere, rarely explained
item.dc:creator: Felipe Dana | AP
item.description: The outskirts of the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv are beginning to have the feel of an open-air morgue

item.title: Zurich Ring Cycle focuses on dysfunctional family of gods
item.dc:creator: Ronald Blum | AP
item.description: Andreas Homoki’s production of Richard Wagner’s “Das Rheingold” that opened at the Zurich Opera is a family affair, stripping Wagner’s mythology of usual trappings, instead laser-focused on a dysfunctional, brooding bunch consumed by greed

item.title: Female Indigenous leader takes office in Panama
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: The first elected female leader of Panama’s Wounaan Indigenous group has taken office

item.title: Thousands flee after clashes erupt in embattled Iraqi town
item.dc:creator: Samya Kullab and Salar Salim | AP
item.description: An Iraqi Kurdish official says over 3,000 people have fled the northern Iraqi town of Sinjar and surrounding areas following clashes between the army and a militia group linked with Turkish Kurdish insurgents
